title: Ticket #2794: Schedd becomes unresponsive when running short lived jobs
description:
Running the followig: 

#!/bin/bash
for i in `seq 100`; do
        /bin/sh -c "condor_submit ./generic_submit"
        /bin/sh -c "condor_q"
        sleep 5
done

where generic_submit ==

executable=/bin/sleep
arguments=1
log=$(cluster).$(process)_generic_submit.log
output=$(cluster).$(process)_generic_submit.out
error=$(cluster).$(process)_generic_submit.err
queue 32

Can consistently get the schedd to become unresponsive. It appears that it's in some kind of deadlock condition B/C all my slots are claimed/idle, and the machine is not CPU bound.

It occurs ~ 3rd or 4th claim reuse on a 8-core machine. The script only succeeds again once the queue is empty.

NOTE: I do not see the above behavior in 7.6 series.
remarks:
2012-Jan-31 15:04:39 by nwp:
I ran exactly the test specified; I am not able to reproduce on my machine (llunet.cs.wisc.edu). Schedd responsiveness is normal, and slots stay claimed/busy.

2012-Feb-01 14:34:09 by tstclair:
I will run a profile tomorrow and try to determine where it is spending it's time.

2012-Feb-03 16:10:18 by tstclair:
All of the time appears to be blocked in fsync calls.

Of note, this may be stressed my local machine b/c I'm running btrfs.

Again, it doesn't appear to behave this way on 7.6.

2012-Feb-06 15:06:46 by tstclair:
strace -c

2012-Feb-06 18:27:51 by nwp:
Again, I cannot reproduce. If anything, the current master (c0c5d40) is snappier and much more responsive than 7.6. Comparison of fsync calls: For the same job run, I had the same number, 330, in both cases.

2012-Feb-06 18:32:55 by nwp:
For 7.6 (4d943fb): 
nwp:~/2794$ strace -c -e fsync -p 22995
Process 22995 attached - interrupt to quit
Process 22995 detached
% time     seconds  usecs/call     calls    errors syscall
------ ----------- ----------- --------- --------- ----------------
100.00    0.098992         300       330           fsync
------ ----------- ----------- --------- --------- ----------------
100.00    0.098992                   330           total

For current master (c0c5d40): 

nwp:~/2794$ strace -c -e fsync -p 5517
Process 5517 attached - interrupt to quit
Process 5517 detached
% time     seconds  usecs/call     calls    errors syscall
------ ----------- ----------- --------- --------- ----------------
100.00    0.082986         251       330           fsync
------ ----------- ----------- --------- --------- ----------------
100.00    0.082986                   330           total

Looks to me like master is 16.2 per cent faster than 7.6, as 

(0.098992-0.082986)/0.098992 = .16168983352190075965

2012-Feb-06 21:41:41 by tstclair:
How many jobs did you measure? Were you running the script above? For how long.. etc. etc. I'll post my results in the am.

2012-Feb-07 00:36:58 by nwp:
For the results above, I ran with `seq 5` instead of `seq 100`. When I ran with `seq 100`, the results are basically the same: scale up by 20, so you get 6603 fsync calls instead of 330.

2012-Feb-07 09:34:03 by tstclair:
I've attached the results of the run and despite my initial strace theory it appears to be incorrect, however my initial assertion appears correct. When you look at the submission time..

1-9 for 7.6.7 ~ 2:24

1-9 for 7.7.6 ~ 5:23

2012-Feb-07 10:04:47 by nwp:
I get opposite results: 0:55 for 7.7.6 and 2:20 for 7.6.7

2012-Feb-08 11:09:40 by tstclair:
Going to bump *this to see if other folks see it, b/c nathan can not repro. I can consistently repro, see attached bitz, plus check my public loc for full logs.

In looking through the logs nothing stands out, so I will bump and wait for repro.

2012-Feb-08 13:45:18 by tannenba:
This ticket was initially created as a child of #2790, but upon further investigation it does not seem at all related, so I am removing this parent/child relationship.
